posts.cooked:
I am new and trying to get the Romi working using the RomiReference project in VisualStudioCode. I can connect to Romi via a browser. Romi is using the Bridge network. I edited build.gradle to set the correct IP for Romi. When I run the RomiReference, I get:

Simulator GUI Initialized! HAL Extensions: Successfully loaded extension HAL Extensions: Attempting to load: halsim_ds_socket DriverStationSocket Initializing. DriverStationSocket Initialized! HAL Extensions: Successfully loaded extension HAL Extensions: Attempting to load: halsim_ws_client HALSim WS Client Extension Initializing HALSimWS Initialized Will attempt to connect to ws://192.168.86.207:3300/wpilibws Connection Attempt HALSim WS Client Extension Initialized 1HAL Extensions: Successfully loaded extension

********** Robot program starting ********** HALSimWS: WebSocket Connected Default simulationInit() method… Override me! Default simulationPeriodic() method… Override me! Button A Released NT: server: client CONNECTED: 192.168.86.207 port 60344

The Robot Simulation program starts. I dragged the Xbox Controller in the System Joysticks to the Joysticks window. The Joysticks window shows the values changing when I press the joysticks. However, when I go to Robot State and set it to Teleoperated, nothing happens on Romi when I press the joysticks.

What am I missing? I hope it’s not something stupid on my part.

Thanks

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
I have some odd questions that may help a bit.

Are you trying the correct stick on the Xbox?

Also, if you press the A button on the Romi, does it report in the terminal?

Does the Romi have fresh batteries?

Have you updated the Romi firmware?

Are you getting any errors in the terminal?

I have tried every joystick and button on the Xbox controller and none of them produce an action on Romi.

On program startup, the terminal shows: HALSimWS: WebSocket Connected Default simulationInit() method… Override me! Default simulationPeriodic() method… Override me! Button A Released NT: server: client CONNECTED: 192.168.86.207 port 44176 NT: server: client CONNECTED: 192.168.86.207 port 44150

I did not press the Romi button A to get the message “Button A Released” above. When I press the button A on Romi, it does not cause any additional terminal message.

I swapped all 6 batteries with new ones and it did not have any effect.

I just started working with Romi so I have a freshly downloaded RaspberryPi image and Romi firmware. The Romi Service Version (reported on the web page) is 1.4.0. I did flash the Romi firmware yesterday.

Once the application starts (see log messages above), no further terminal messages occur until I shut down the application.

Thanks for the interest in helping me. Todd

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
A few ideas to check

When you switch to autonomous mode does the robot move at all?

When you are in the simulation window (glass) in the other devices window do the gyro readings move when you move the Romi with your hand.

When switching to autonomous mode the motors do not move at all. In fact, I have never been able to get the motors to move at all.

When the Robot Simulation is running, if I manually move Romi the RomiGyro values do change. So, the Romi is communicating with the PC robot simulator.

Is there another way to test the motor function on Romi? Could I have gotten a faulty Romi?

Todd

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
There are probably better experts here than me but I can tell you somethings I would do next.

Post pictures here of your Romi and include close up of the motors, and the connections to the Romi board.

Swap the motors around and make sure all the physical connection look good, look for any broken solder joints.

Contact Pololu customer support.

Possibly look on the Pololu site for the non-FRC setup instructions and see if you can get the motors spinning with out the FRC software.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
We have seen this behavior before (but never with both motors). There are a few thoughts I have.

Is the magnet pushed against the encoder board? If it is, the motor will not turn.

Is the magnet pushed against the encoder board? If it is, the motor will not turn.

Did you buy the motors with pre-assembled encoder boeads (like the FRC kit). If not, it is possible to drip solder into the motor and fuse it. In that event, I would contact Pololu support. They are helpful.

Did you buy the motors with pre-assembled encoder boeads (like the FRC kit). If not, it is possible to drip solder into the motor and fuse it. In that event, I would contact Pololu support. They are helpful.

Here is a link to the Pololu docs.

One more software thought. Did the port numbers for the motors change in the software (they should be 0 and 1)?

link_counts.title: Pololu - Romi Robot Kit for FIRST - Red

posts.cooked:
I believe the ports are correct: // The Romi has the left and right motors set to // PWM channels 0 and 1 respectively private final Spark m_leftMotor = new Spark(0); private final Spark m_rightMotor = new Spark(1);

I purchased the kit as the FRC kit so the encoder was pre-assembled. Visually inspecting the magnet looks fine. All solder connections look fine.

The team bought 2 Romi’s. I will get the other Romi and test with that one to help determine if the problem is on the Romi side or the PC side. This will happen in a day or two.

Todd

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked: Excellent. Keep us posted. It is possible to have the motor attached, but the breakout board not seated in the header correctly, but in our experience, the motors work, but encoders do not when that happens. Also, We have not had this happen to both motors, only one.

You could test the raw functionality of the Romi itself by loading some of the Arduino sample programs onto the Romi controller. The RotationResist sample is useful for testing motors as well as getting a sense for the amount of gyro drift you can expect to encounter out of each individual Romi.

You would use the Arduino IDE to load the samples directly onto the Romi from your PC.

Library to help interface with the on-board hardware of the Romi 32U4 Control Board - GitHub - pololu/romi-32u4-arduino-library: Library to help interface with the on-board hardware of the Romi 32U...

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked:
I have had similar issues with ROMIs that students were using and even the one that I was just messing with this afternoon. I have the PC connected to the ROMI network, ROMI web client is accessible, sometimes the gyro reports values back sometimes not. Just now, I was able to resolve the issue by rebooting my PC and the ROMI, but I also had no output from the gyro at all, unlike what you’re reporting. Eventually, my battery level got too low (about 7.15 or so) and the whole thing froze in the middle of driving, so I’m recharging.

In the cases where we’ve had problems with students using them, switching to another computer caused the ROMI to work again, so we think it is the PC in question that seems to be having the issue. Since the code runs on the PC and needs to send commands to the ROMI to move, it doesn’t surprise me that we’d see the code running as if all systems were go, but the underlying commands just weren’t making it to the hardware at some level.

I think the next time I see this I’m going to get some video of various stats from the ROMI webclient, such as networking, battery, CPU, etc… and compare to a working ROMI or the same ROMI on a PC that works, mainly to see if it’s a networking issue.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
That does seem odd and frustrating as well. We have not seen that behavior (Knock on wood).

There are some situations in which the code crashes, and then we cannot reconnect to the Romi becuase we already have an active socket. A soft reboot of the code on the web interface fixes this without needing to reboot  the whole robot.

Also, Windows firewall is finicky about bridged network connections. This is especially true if there is no Internet on the other end.

However, in each of those instances, we have seen no updated Romi data in the simulator window.

This post reminds me. Whenever we see odd behavior on the Romi, we enable the web console logging in the Romi tab  and watch that as well. Sonetimes that points to a solution (that is where we see that already have an active socket message).

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked: Well, I was able to figure out that at least one student had coded two DifferentialDrives into their drive subsystem such that both must have been interfering with each other. Once we eliminated one of them, he was able to get a ROMI moving. So, that’s one less mystery. FYI, they had been getting warning messages about ‘MotorSafety’ output not updated often enough, because they’d mixed in some code we’d been using to write a simulator example. But, I’ll keep an eye out for the symptom I experienced this weekend.

SOLUTION FOUND: I believe my original problem was a bad microSD card.

I got a second Romi and plugged in the same microSD card I was using on the first Romi. The problem still existed … no motor action at all. I then decided to start from scratch.  When I used BalenaEtcher to write the Pi image to the SD card, my Windows10 laptop blue-screened. After that, I tried to just read the SD card and could not.

Switching to a new microSD card, I used BalenaEtcher to write the Pi image and booted up the original Romi. I flashed the Romi again. Now, things work properly … motors spin.

It surprises me that I could connect to the Pi via the web page, could communicate with it via the Simulator, and yet something was not working. However, all I changed was the SD card and now things are working fine. And, the old SD card is definitely bad; I’ve tried reading it with 2 different computers and neither could read it at all.

Thanks for all the help, hints, etc.

Todd
